perturbation.changed_text: E. PAYMENT. perturbation.explanation: The original contract specifies payment terms within a certain timeframe, indicated by '[*]' which is intended to be filled with a specific number of days. Modifying this to 90 days for standard payments and 120 days for initial orders introduces a legal contradiction because such extended payment terms could violate California's prompt payment laws (since the contract is governed by California law, as stated in section 19). These laws generally mandate shorter payment periods, especially for certain types of businesses, and unreasonably delaying payments could lead to legal repercussions.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Prompt Payment Laws (potentially Cal. Civ. Code §§ 3302, 1719, depending on the nature of the underlying transaction)

perturbation.original_text: D. NETGEAR reserves the right to change the discount schedule, policy or program, whether referred to in the Agreement or set forth in an Exhibit to the Agreement. For changes which, in NETGEAR's opinion, may adversely affect Distributor, NETGEAR will provide thirty (30) days notice, or such longer period as NETGEAR deems appropriate, prior to the effective date of such change.
perturbation.changed_text: D. NETGEAR reserves the right to change the discount schedule, policy or program, whether referred to in the Agreement or set forth in an Exhibit to the Agreement. NETGEAR will provide seven (7) days notice prior to the effective date of such change, regardless of whether the changes may adversely affect Distributor.
perturbation.explanation: California law implies a covenant of good faith and fair dealing in all contracts. Reducing the notice period to seven days, especially for changes that adversely affect the distributor, could be deemed commercially unreasonable and a violation of this implied covenant. The original text provides 30 days' notice for adverse changes, which is a more reasonable timeframe; this change introduces a shorter, potentially unfair notice period.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (California Contract Law)

perturbation.original_text: B. TERMINATION. This Agreement may be canceled at any time without cause, by either party upon ninety (90) days written notice to the other party. Either party may terminate this Agreement immediately if (i) the other party becomes insolvent, files or has filed against it a petition in bankruptcy, or ceases doing business; or (ii) the other party fails to cure a material breach of the Agreement within thirty (30) days after receipt of written notice of such breach from the party not in default. Upon termination of the Agreement by NETGEAR for Distributor's breach, NETGEAR may cancel all of Distributor's unfulfilled orders without further obligation. This Agreement may be terminated at any time without cause by either party upon ninety (90) days written notice to the other party.
perturbation.changed_text: B. TERMINATION. This Agreement may be canceled at any time without cause, by either party upon thirty (30) days written notice to the other party. Either party may terminate this Agreement immediately if (i) the other party becomes insolvent, files or has filed against it a petition in bankruptcy, or ceases doing business; or (ii) the other party fails to cure a material breach of the Agreement within ten (10) days after receipt of written notice of such breach from the party not in default. Upon termination of the Agreement by NETGEAR for Distributor's breach, NETGEAR may cancel all of Distributor's unfulfilled orders without further obligation. This Agreement may be terminated at any time without cause by either party upon thirty (30) days written notice to the other party.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a material breach from thirty days to ten days may be considered unreasonably short, especially considering the complexities of business operations and the potential for disputes. Under California law, contracts must be interpreted in a way that is commercially reasonable. A ten-day cure period may not provide sufficient time for a party to rectify a significant breach, particularly in a complex distributor agreement, potentially conflicting with principles of fairness and reasonableness implied in contract law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Principles of Contract Interpretation and Good Faith and Fair Dealing (California Contract Law)
